title: Frank LaRose
deleted: LaRose sponsored a bill to eliminate six days of early voting (SB 238) and to prohibit county Board of Elections from sending out unsolicited absentee voting applications.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2014/02/ohio_house_passes_bills_to_cha.html | title=Ohio House passes bills to change absentee ballot rules, eliminate six days of early voting|author=Jackie Borchardt|website=Cleveland.com| date=February 20, 2014}}</ref> In 2016, he voted for SB 296, introduced by Rep. [[Bill Seitz]], which would require a monetary payment in order to extend voting hours at any vote center for any reason.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/05/24/ohio-voting-hours-bill/84874672/|date=May 24, 2016|title=Bill to require cash for extending voting hours speeds toward Ohio gov|author=Jessie Balmert|work=USA Today|access-date=March 14, 2021}}</ref>

By 2014, LaRose had supported five major [[abortion]] restriction laws.{{cite news|url=https://www.the-daily-record.com/opinion/20140429/letter-larose-is-pro-life-conservative|work=The Daily Record|date=April 29, 2014|title=Letter: LaRose is pro-life conservative}}{{Better source needed|date=August 2020}} However, the anti-abortion advocacy group Ohio Right to Life endorsed his opponent in the 2014 Republican primary.{{Cite web|last=Gomez|first=Henry J.|date=March 10, 2014|title=Ohio Right to Life passes on U.S. Rep. Dave Joyce, endorses primary challenger Matt Lynch|url=https://www.cleveland.com/open/2014/03/ohio_right_to_life_passes_on_u.html|access-date=August 8, 2020|website=Cleveland.com}}
- {{Cite web|title=Right to Life backs Dems, tea partier, gay in "diverse" endorsements|url=https://www.dispatch.com/article/20140310/BLOGS/303109825|access-date=August 8, 2020|website=The Columbus Dispatch}}
In 2015, Larose voted for SB 127, a 20-week abortion ban, and cosponsored HB 294, which prohibited public funds for abortion services.

In 2016, Larose supported HB 493, a "[[heartbeat bill]]", even though similar bills have been unanimously blocked by the judiciary in several other states.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.cleveland.com/court-justice/index.ssf/2016/12/ohio_heartbeat_bill_how_conser_1.html |title = Ohio's 'heartbeat bill': How conservative judges in other states gutted similar laws|website=Cleveland.com|date =December 8, 2016}}</ref> In 2017, he voted for SB 28, which would require the burial or cremation of fetal remains, identical to a similar bill which had been blocked in Texas.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://verdict.justia.com/2017/01/31/federal-judge-buries-unconstitutional-texas-law-treatment-fetal-remains |title = Federal Judge Buries Unconstitutional Texas Law on the Treatment of Fetal Remains}}</ref>

In 2017, he sponsored legislation to prevent women from having abortions after a fetal diagnosis of [[Down syndrome]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/11/ohio_senate_passes_down_syndro.html|title=Ohio Senate passes Down syndrome abortion ban|date=November 15, 2017|access-date=November 27, 2017|work=The Cleveland Plain Dealer}}</ref> He also voted for SB 145, which bans certain abortion procedures.
The [[American Conservative Union]] gave him a 100% evaluation for 2017.{{Citation needed|date=August 2020}}

title: Frank LaRose
deleted: LaRose sponsored a bill to eliminate six days of early voting (SB 238) and to prohibit county Board of Elections from sending out unsolicited absentee voting applications.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2014/02/ohio_house_passes_bills_to_cha.html | title=Ohio House passes bills to change absentee ballot rules, eliminate six days of early voting|author=Jackie Borchardt|website=Cleveland.com| date=February 20, 2014}}</ref> In 2016, he voted for SB 296, introduced by Rep. In 2016, his legislative aide, Jessica Koehler, joined Ohio's Right to Life as its director of legislative affairs.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.ohiolife.org/ohio_right_to_life_announces_new_director_and_staff |title = Ohio Right to Life Announces New Director and Staff}}</ref>
In 2015, Larose voted for SB 127, a 20-week abortion ban, and cosponsored HB 294, which prohibited public funds for abortion services.

In 2016, Larose supported HB 493, a "[[heartbeat bill]]", even though similar bills have been unanimously blocked by the judiciary in several other states.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.cleveland.com/court-justice/index.ssf/2016/12/ohio_heartbeat_bill_how_conser_1.html |title = Ohio's 'heartbeat bill': How conservative judges in other states gutted similar laws|website=Cleveland.com|date =December 8, 2016}}</ref> In 2017, he voted for SB 28, which would require the burial or cremation of fetal remains, identical to a similar bill which had been blocked in Texas.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://verdict.justia.com/2017/01/31/federal-judge-buries-unconstitutional-texas-law-treatment-fetal-remains |title = Federal Judge Buries Unconstitutional Texas Law on the Treatment of Fetal Remains}}</ref>

In 2017, he sponsored legislation to prevent women from having abortions after a fetal diagnosis of [[Down syndrome]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2017/11/ohio_senate_passes_down_syndro.html|title=Ohio Senate passes Down syndrome abortion ban|date=November 15, 2017|access-date=November 27, 2017|work=The Cleveland Plain Dealer}}</ref> He also voted for SB 145, which bans certain abortion procedures.
The [[American Conservative Union]] gave him a 100% evaluation for 2017.{{Citation needed|date=August 2020}}
